action.action-desc: Mr. Cleaver (for himself, Mrs. McBath, Mr. Payne, Mr. Moulton, Ms. Chu, Ms. Ross, Mr. DeSaulnier, Ms. Titus, Mr. Davis of North Carolina, Mr. Casten, Ms. Sewell, Ms. Wilson of Florida, Mr. Khanna, Mrs. Hayes, Mr. Kilmer, Mr. Takano, Mr. Johnson of Georgia, Ms. Barragán, Mr. Nadler, Ms. Kamlager-Dove, Ms. Velázquez, Ms. Norton, Mr. Bowman, Ms. Wild, Ms. Davids of Kansas, Mr. Carter of Louisiana, Mrs. Watson Coleman, Ms. Brown, Mr. García of Illinois, Mr. McGovern, and Mr. Cárdenas) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Energy and Commerce, and in addition to the Committee on Education and the Workforce, for a period to be subsequently determined by the Speaker, in each case for consideration of such provisions as fall within the jurisdiction of the committee concerned

form.official-title: To amend the Public Health Service Act to authorize certain grants (for youth suicide early intervention and prevention strategies) to be used for school personnel in elementary and secondary schools and students in secondary schools to receive student suicide awareness and prevention training, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Cady Housh and Gemesha Thomas Student Suicide Prevention Act of 2023.

paragraph.text: According to the National Institutes of Health, suicide is the second leading cause of death for young people between the ages of 10 and 34. Between 2007 and 2018, the national suicide rate among persons ages 1 to 24 increased 57.4 percent. From 2018 to 2021, the national suicide rate among persons ages 10 to 24 increased by 2.8 percent.

According to the 2021 Youth Risk Behaviors Survey of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, 22.2 percent of high school students reported seriously considering suicide during the previous 12 months, and 10.2 percent reported actually attempting to take their lives during that period.
Eighty percent of students show warning signs before attempting suicide.
Prevention and awareness training will equip individuals to become aware of the warning signs of suicide, identify students in crisis, and provide resources for help.
Research shows that inquiring about suicide ideation, or discussing suicide in terms of recognizing risk factors and prevention methods—

subparagraph.text: does not increase the chance of suicide; and
in fact, can lower the risk of suicide.

paragraph.text: Sexual minority youth (LGBT+) are almost five times more likely to have attempted suicide compared to their heterosexual peers. According to the Trevor Project’s 2022 National Survey on LGBTQ Youth Mental Health, 45 percent of LGBT+ youth seriously considered suicide in the past year including more than half of transgender and nonbinary youth and 1 in 3 cisgender youth. Additionally, 14 percent of LGBT+ youth attempted suicide in that same period, including nearly 1 in 5 transgender and nonbinary youth and 1 in 10 cisgender youth.

According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, emergency department visits among adolescents increased during the pandemic. During the period of February 21 to March 20 in 2021, suspected suicide attempt emergency department visits were 50.6 percent higher among girls aged 12 to 17 years than during the same period in 2019.

section.text: It is the sense of the Congress that—

paragraph.text: student suicide awareness, prevention training, and response materials should be available to all school personnel, including administrative personnel, teachers, counselors, and other school leaders;
States should give autonomy to each local educational agency to—

subparagraph.text: adopt a policy with respect to student suicide awareness and prevention; and

work collaboratively with local organizations, youth mental health experts, health care providers, and the Secretary of Health and Human Services to implement training for school personnel and students, including by sharing and disseminating—

clause.text: information that is evidence-informed or promising on student suicide prevention;

paragraph.text: the Secretary of Health and Human Services should identify the highest unmet needs, specifically with at-risk student populations, such as—

subparagraph.text: students living with mental health conditions;
students living with substance use disorders;
students who have engaged in self-harm or have attempted suicide; and
students experiencing homelessness or out-of-home settings;

paragraph.text: schools should offer these services to students in grades 9 through 12, with the support of organizations with demonstrated expertise in cultural competency, suicide awareness, response, and prevention training;
students who receive such training should not be taught to be counselors, but rather should be educated on how to—

subparagraph.text: recognize signs of suicide and depression;
report these signs to appropriate staff; and
identify sources of care and support; and

paragraph.text: schools should utilize school-based mental health professionals and other community partnerships.

section.header: Student suicide awareness and prevention training

subsection.header: Additional authorized use of grant funds
subsection.text: Section 520E(a) of the Public Health Service Act (42 U.S.C. 290bb–36(a)) is amended—

paragraph.text: in paragraph (4), by striking and at the end;
in paragraph (5), by striking the period at the end and inserting ; and; and
by adding at the end the following:

establish and implement a statewide policy requiring school personnel in elementary and secondary schools and students in secondary schools to complete student emotional well-being, mental health, and suicide awareness and prevention training in accordance with subsection (d).

subsection.text: Section 520E of the Public Health Service Act (42 U.S.C. 290bb–36(a)), as amended by subsection (a), is further amended—

paragraph.text: by redesignating subsections (d) through (m) as subsections (e) through (n), respectively; and
by inserting after subsection (c) the following:

subsection.header: Requirements for student suicide awareness and training programs

paragraph.text: As a condition on receipt of funds under subsection (a)(6), an applicant shall agree to use the funds to establish or implement a statewide policy—

subparagraph.text: requiring school personnel in elementary and secondary schools and students in secondary schools to complete student emotional well-being, mental health, and suicide awareness and prevention training that—

clause.text: includes at least one classroom session each school year;

subclause.text: the warning signs of, and elevated risk factors for, poor emotional well-being, mental health issues, and suicide of oneself and of others;
suggested responses to such warning signs;
further suicide awareness and prevention resources; and
the method and manner of making an appropriate referral to a school-based mental health services provider; and

subparagraph.text: requiring, with respect to such school personnel, that such training include training on—

clause.text: cultural competency and intersectionality sensitivity; and
an overview of applicable Federal, State, and local law concerning reporting requirements.

paragraph.text: As used in subsection (a)(6) and this subsection:

subparagraph.text: The term evidence-informed means informed by practices that—

clause.text: use the best available research and practice knowledge to guide program design and implementation;
allow for innovation while incorporating the lessons learned from the existing research literature; and
are responsive to families’ cultural backgrounds, community values, and individual preferences.

subparagraph.text: The term school-based mental health services provider includes a State-licensed or State-certified school counselor, school psychologist, school social worker, or other State-licensed or certified mental health professional qualified under State law to provide mental health services to children and adolescents.

clause.text: principals or other heads of a school; other professional instructional staff (such as staff involved in curriculum development, staff development, or operating library, media, and computer centers); specialized instructional support personnel such as school counselors, school social workers, and school psychologists; and other qualified professional personnel, such as school nurses, speech language pathologists, and school librarians, involved in providing assessment, diagnosis, counseling, and educational, therapeutic, and other necessary services; and
other school employees and contractors who interact with students, including bus drivers, cafeteria workers, coaches, janitorial staff, and after-school program employees.

subsection.text: Subsection (n) of section 520E of the Public Health Service Act (42 U.S.C. 290bb–36), as redesignated by subsection (b)(1), is amended—

paragraph.text: by striking For the purpose and inserting the following:
For the purpose
by striking $40,000,000 and inserting $48,000,000; and
by adding at the end the following:

Of the amounts made available to carry out this section for a fiscal year, not less than 15 percent of such amounts shall be used for grants or cooperative agreements to carry out subsection (a)(6) (to establish and implement a statewide policy requiring school personnel in elementary and secondary schools and students in secondary schools to complete student emotional well-being, mental health, and suicide awareness and prevention training).
